You walk away before it ends, the taste of ash thick on your tongue, the smell of burned hair following you down the road.

choices.optionText: Drive the mule out = Charge through smoke and flame, cut it loose, drive it to safety
choices.optionPreview: Charge through smoke and flame, cut it loose, drive it to safety

single.text:
You do not wait for permission. You wrap cloth across your mouth and run into the smoke. The heat is immediate and savage. The world narrows to the sound of the mule's braying, a beacon in the grey. You find it tangled in a collapsed cart, harness twisted around the axle. Your hands work blind, fumbling with knots and buckles while the flames crawl closer. The mule kicks, wild with fear, and catches you in the ribs. You taste blood. But the last strap comes free and you seize its halter, dragging it forward into the smoke, praying you remember which direction is out.
  You do. Barely. You emerge gasping, the mule bolting past you toward open ground. The fire has taken half the field. The woman and the farmer beat at the edges with their sacks, trying to contain it, but the wind is relentless. By the time it burns itself out against the road, the damage is done. The farmer does not speak. He catches the mule, strokes its neck, and stares at the blackened ruin of his harvest. You leave him there. The children watch you go, silent as stones.

choices.optionText: Walk on = This is not your field, not your village, not your concern
choices.optionPreview: This is not your field, not your village, not your concern

single.text:
You meet the woman's eyes and say nothing. Her expression does not change. She expected this, perhaps. She turns away, back to the field, and begins beating at the flames with her sack. Alone. The farmer remains frozen. His children cry.
  You walk. Behind you the smoke rises higher, a grey pillar against the sky. The mule's screaming follows you for a time, then stops. You do not look back. By the time you reach the next village, the column is visible for miles, a marker of ruin that every farmer and merchant will see and remember. In Aldgate, bread prices will rise. Tempers will fray. Someone will pay for this. But it will not be you. You are already gone, a stranger passing through, and the ring on your hand catches the light like a promise no one asked you to keep.

encounters.title: The Grain Cart
encounters.body:
The cart sits alone at the crossroads, tilted on one broken axle. Sacks of grain are piled high beneath canvas, the lashings still tight, the whole load intact and untouched. No driver. No mule. Just the cart and the flies and the afternoon heat pressing down on the wheat fields.

You see the problem before you reach it. The axle didn't break from weight or rot. Someone pried the wheel off and left it ten paces down the road, half-hidden in the ditch. The cart's been abandoned deliberately, set here like bait. Or a message.

Movement catches your eye near the cart. A young man, nearly a boy, is struggling to pull a full sack from the wagon. He freezes under your gaze, pauses a long moment to think, then shouts "take one for yourself or walk on, stranger. It's been a hard year and this is the first bit of luck my family's had."

The smell of overripe wheat rolls across the fields. Cicadas drone in the heat.

choices.optionText: Take the grain = Perhaps it's your lucky day as well
choices.optionPreview: Perhaps it's your lucky day as well

single.text:
Your hands work quickly, lifting a sack onto your shoulder. The weight unbalances you, but you'll manage to the next settlement.
  You turn to find the cart's owner, two guards at his side. He sees the bag immediately. His eyes find your ring, and his face goes cold with calculation. "I had expected to travel three day with that grain, but here we have a buyer with ready coin. Just one sack then? Let me check my ledger."
  You curse your ill luck, but pay. The guards watch the coin change hands, bored witnesses to a transaction they've seen a dozen times. The merchant smiles, all teeth, and climbs back onto his repaired cart. The boy and his siblings are gone, vanished into the wheat. Your pack is lighter by coin and heavier by grain.

choices.optionText: Persuade the man to leave = Something feels amiss here
choices.optionPreview: Something feels amiss here

branches.text: You've seen this trap in three towns before. The owner and his men are hiding nearby, keen to extort silver from anyone foolish enough to steal from the cart. The boy's eyes widen as you explain the game, then he drops the sack and melts into the wheat without a word. Sure enough, as you continue down the road, you catch the glint of steel behind the stone wall where the merchant and his hired muscle wait for easier marks.

fallback.text:
You clear your throat and set about the tale of Old Man Yaniv and the grimlet—carefully, properly, with the necessary scaffolding. The grimlet, you explain, is not merely a creature of shadow and riddles but a cautionary mechanism in furred form, and its threefold bargains must be understood in sequence if one is to appreciate their symmetry. There are digressions, brief but essential, on the curing of jorgo root, on the contractual ambiguity of sunset, on the moral hazard of speaking imprecisely to entities who delight in precision. Somewhere during your clarification of root preparation methods, the boy's attention begins to drift, and you, ever attentive to pedagogy, pivot smoothly to the more illustrative case of Yaniv and the Magic Fish.
    This second account you deliver with renewed vigor, outlining each wish and its unintended corollary, tracing the arc of folly with a steady finger as though diagramming it in the air. You conclude with a small, satisfied flourish, certain the lesson has landed squarely. When you turn to gauge the effect, however, there is only the cart, the mule, and the long shadows stretching across the road. The boy, presumably fortified with wisdom, has seen fit to depart before the final summary.

choices.optionText: Give this ruffian a thrashing = You'll not let theft go unpunished
choices.optionPreview: You'll not let theft go unpunished

branches.text: The boy takes one look at your stance and drops the sack, grain spilling across the dirt as he scrambles backward. He turns and runs into the wheat, the stalks swallowing him whole, his panicked breathing fading into the cicada drone. You continue down the road, leaving the tilted cart and its intact cargo to bake in the afternoon sun.

fallback.text:
You stride toward the youth with purpose. He does not cower. Instead, his shoulders tense, his feet shift to balance, and you glimpse in his stance some trace of training, or at least of many fights survived.
    He moves before you close the distance. The sack of grain, still gripped in both hands, rises and swings toward you with surprising force. It catches you across the chest and shoulder, a dull, heavy impact that staggers you backward. The weight of it, the suddenness, sends you sprawling into the dirt.
    Before you can rise, he is on you. He straddles your torso, pinning you against the ground with his knees, and his fists descend in rapid succession. The blows land across your jaw, your cheekbone, your brow. You taste copper. Your vision flashes white with each strike. He breathes hard through his teeth, his face taut with desperation, and you feel the weight of his intention: he means to end you here, to beat you senseless or worse.
    Then, abruptly, he stops. He springs off you and bolts, sprinting down the road toward the wheat fields. You roll to your side, gasping, the dust thick in your throat.
    Hoofbeats and the creak of leather reach your ears. You push yourself to your knees, blinking blood from one eye, and see three figures approaching: a broad man in merchant's garb astride a mule, flanked by two guards with cudgels in hand. The merchant reins in near the cart, his gaze sweeping the scene. He sees you, bloodied and still half-prone in the dirt, and his expression hardens.
    "Looks like the thieves turned on each other," he says, voice flat and certain. "One of them is still here."
    The guards move to either side of you. You raise a hand, wipe at your mouth, and speak slowly, forcing steadiness into your voice. You tell him you came upon the boy stealing from his cart. You tell him you meant to protect his grain, to stop the theft before it worsened.
    The merchant's eyes narrow. He glances at the cart, at the sacks still piled beneath their canvas, the lashings intact. He looks back to you, doubt plain in his face.
    "Nothing's been taken," he says after a long pause. "So there's no claim for a crime."
    One of the guards prods you with the end of his cudgel, a silent command to rise. You do, slowly, your ribs aching where the boy's knees pressed down. The merchant watches you stand, his jaw tight, his hand resting on the pommel of a short knife at his belt.
    "You'll move along now," he says. "And keep to your own road."
    You nod once, gather what dignity remains, and turn away from the cart. As you walk, you feel the merchant's gaze fixed on your back, heavy and mistrustful, until the crossroads and the broken cart are far behind you.

encounters.title: The Courier
encounters.body:
The Kesharat courier stands in full sun, sweat darkening the collar of his rumpled official coat. The leather document case lies in the dust between his boots and the clan trader's sandals. The trader picked it up when the courier dropped it—fumbled it, really, after the man made some crack about plateau illiteracy loud enough for the whole watering station to hear. Now the trader holds it at arm's length, recounting the insult word for word to the gathering crowd. Laughter ripples through them. The courier's face has gone red, though whether from heat or humiliation is hard to say.

You catch the shift in the crowd's mood before the courier does. The laughter has an edge now. Someone mutters about arrogant lowlanders. A woman spits in the dust. The trader is still talking, working them like a merchant working a sale, and the courier keeps demanding his property back in that clipped administrative accent that makes everything sound like a reprimand. The signet ring on your hand catches light—the Merchant Guild mark that means you walk between worlds, neither clan nor Kesharat but trusted by both when coin is involved. The courier sees it. His eyes fix on you like a drowning man spotting driftwood.

The trader wants an apology. The courier would sooner eat glass. And the crowd—wind carries their voices across the exposed stone, a low buzz of old resentments given sudden shape. If they lay hands on him, the Kesharat will answer it. Not here, not now. But somewhere a clan will wake to soldiers at their gates, and a debt will be collected that has nothing to do with justice and everything to do with the appearance of authority. The elder under the awning hasn't moved, but his eyes are open. Watching.

The trader holds the case higher. The crowd presses closer. The courier's hand drifts toward his belt where no weapon hangs.

choices.optionText: PERSUADE the trader = Appeal to the trader's sense of self-preservation and clan honor
choices.optionPreview: Appeal to the trader's sense of self-preservation and clan honor

conditional.preamble: You step into the gap between them. The words come measured, pitched for the crowd as much as the trader. The Kesharat remembers insults like the plateau remembers water. Not here, not today, but someone will pay. A cousin's caravan stopped at a checkpoint. A clan's grazing rights questioned by men with ledgers and swords. The trader's eyes narrow, but you see the calculation there. You turn the signet ring so the mark catches light. The Merchant Guild has carried messages between these worlds for three generations. You know what retribution looks like when it crosses borders.

branches.text: The trader lowers the case. Not a surrender, but a repositioning. He addresses the crowd, not the courier. Says he found property that wasn't his and returned it as clan law demands, insult or no insult. The case lands in the dust at the courier's feet. The courier snatches it up, clutching it like a child with a stolen cake. He nods once to you, stiff and graceless, and retreats toward his mount. The crowd disperses with the slow reluctance of a disappointed audience. The trader meets your eyes. No gratitude there, but recognition. You've given him the story he can tell tonight, the one where he's generous and the lowlander is a fool.

fallback.text: The trader's face hardens. He asks the crowd if they're dogs who roll over when the Kesharat snap their fingers. Someone shouts agreement. You see the moment slip like sand through spread fingers. The trader opens the case, breaks the wax seal with his thumb. Papers spill into the wind. The courier lunges. Three men catch him, pin his arms, not gently. No blows fall, but the message is written in grip and stance. The courier is released after long minutes, stumbling, papers scattered across twenty paces of plateau stone. He gathers what he can with shaking hands. Doesn't look at you. The crowd watches him leave, and their laughter follows him like carrion birds.

choices.optionText: INTIMIDATE the trader = Use the weight of the Merchant Guild to make the trader yield
choices.optionPreview: Use the weight of the Merchant Guild to make the trader yield

conditional.preamble: You don't raise your voice. Volume is for people without leverage. You show the signet ring, let the sun catch the mark that means every trading post between here and the coast. Ask the trader which clans he sells to. Ask if he's considered how many of them hold Merchant Guild letters of credit. The words land like stones in still water. The crowd shifts, uncertain now. Guild membership isn't just about coin. It's about roads that stay open and goods that cross borders without entanglement. You let the silence stretch.

branches.text: The trader's jaw works. He spits in the dust, but his hand opens. The case drops. He tells the courier to take his trash and his manners back where they came from. The courier grabs the case, cradles it against his chest. Mumbles something that might be thanks to you, might be a curse. The trader turns his back, loud conversation about anyone who needs outsiders to fight their battles. But the crowd is already losing interest, drifting back to their own transactions. The elder under the awning nods once. You've made your point without making an enemy. The currency of it will spend for a while yet.

fallback.text: The trader laughs. Asks if you're threatening a man for picking up what another dropped. The crowd murmurs, and the sound isn't friendly. Someone mentions a cousin who got squeezed by Guild rates last summer. Another voice adds a grievance about weighted scales. The trader is smiling now, playing to his audience. Your ring suddenly feels heavier, more visible. The courier looks at you with something between hope and panic. The trader tosses the case in the air, catches it. Asks if you'd like to buy it back, maybe. The price is an apology. Not from him. From you. The elder under the awning is watching with the particular attention of someone who will remember what happens next.

choices.optionText: PAY the trader = Offer coin to resolve the situation
choices.optionPreview: Offer coin to resolve the situation

single.text:
You pull the purse from your belt, pour coins into your palm. Silver catches light like water in drought country. Don't address the insult, don't adjudicate who owes what to whom. Just ask what the finder's fee is for lost property. Frame it as custom, as proper form. The trader's eyes fix on your hand. The crowd quiets. Money makes things simple in ways that honor never does.
  The trader names a price. Not outrageous, but not generous either. The courier starts to object, but you silence him with a look. You count out the coins into the trader's palm. The exchange happens with the small ceremony that all plateau transactions demand. The trader hands over the case, bows with theatrical courtesy. Tells the courier that civilized people settle matters with trade, not tantrum. The courier takes the case, face burning. Looks at you with naked relief and something more complicated underneath. You've saved him, but you've also made him small in front of witnesses. The crowd disperses. The elder under the awning returns to his tea. Debt paid, story finished, everyone walks away with something to tell.

choices.optionText: Ignore = Walk past without involvement
choices.optionPreview: Walk past without involvement

single.text:
You adjust your pack and turn toward the road. The courier calls after you, voice cracking with desperation. You keep walking. Behind you the voices rise, the trader's performance reaching its crescendo. The crowd's laughter has teeth in it now. Your boots find the packed earth of the caravan track. Dust plumes with each step. The sounds fade slower than you'd like.
  A half mile on, you hear hoofbeats. The courier passes at a gallop, hunched low, no document case visible. His mount's flanks are lathered. He doesn't look at you. Further still, you pass a woman leading a pack goat. She mentions that some Kesharat fool got himself rolled at the watering station. Lost his papers, lost his dignity, rode off like demons were chasing him. She seems to find it funny. You ask if anyone was hurt. She shrugs. Says the clans know better than to leave marks the Kesharat can see. You walk on. The wind carries dust and distance. Whatever accounting follows will happen far from here, in offices and checkpoints where your ring holds no weight.

encounters.title: Unusual Cargo
encounters.body:
The canyon pass narrows to a stone throat barely wide enough for two carts abreast. A rope barrier blocks the way, strung between iron stakes driven into the cracked earth. Behind it stands a toll-keeper in dusty indigo, arms crossed, while two merchants argue with the practiced intensity of people who know their words won't matter. Their loaded carts sit baking in the harsh sun. 

One merchant keeps fishing in a leather document case at his belt, pulling out stamped tokens, putting them back. The toll-keeper doesn't look at them anymore.

The lead merchant spots your ring while you're still appraising the situation. His relief is immediate and desperate. "Guild authority," he says loudly. He gestures toward the toll-keeper, "This man is trying to rob us. We paid. We have tokens. He says tokens mean nothing now."

The man with the document case pulls out a stamped metal disk and holds it up with some gravity. You can't read the language, but you understand it's a contract of some sort.

The toll-keeper sighs heavily. "I have explained this. All travelers will be searched. It is the new rule. Your tokens do not buy you an exception from the rule." He gestures to a pair of nearby guards, who start walking toward the cart.

The lead merchant leans close to you, voice dropping. "This is robbery. He will search our cargo. He will find so-called contraband. He will steal from both of us." The sealed crate on his middle cart sits roped tight, wax stamps intact along every edge. Too many seals for ordinary cargo.

choices.optionText: Persuade the toll-keeper to reconsider = Use your Guild authority to negotiate a resolution
choices.optionPreview: Use your Guild authority to negotiate a resolution

conditional.preamble: You step between them before the guards reach the crate. "The Guild recognizes passage tokens issued under legitimate clan authority," you say, loud enough for the waiting travelers to hear. "If your clan wishes to renegotiate terms, that conversation happens through formal channels. Not at a rope barrier in the afternoon heat." You turn the ring so the signet catches light. "Unless you want every caravan master from here to the plateaus hearing that clan word means nothing."

branches.text:
The toll-keeper holds your gaze for a long moment, his jaw working as though chewing something bitter. His eyes narrow, measuring the weight of the ring you wear against whatever authority has placed him here at this stone throat. The guards halt mid-stride, their attention fixed on their captain.
    At last he grunts, a sound dragged up from some deep well of pragmatism. He waves one hand sharply, and the guards retreat to their stations without a word. "We will make an exception for the outlander," he says, each word dropping like a stone into still water, "who is unaccustomed to our ways." He moves to the nearest iron stake and begins working the rope free, his fingers quick despite their reluctance. The barrier sags, then falls away entirely. "Tomorrow you will not be so fortunate."
    The lead merchant exhales audibly. He says nothing, perhaps knowing better than to claim victory aloud, and climbs onto his cart. The wheels groan as the mules lean into their harnesses. You watch the sealed crate pass through the gap, its wax stamps catching the brutal sun, still intact.

fallback.text:
The toll-keeper throws back his head and laughs, a sound like stones scraping in a dry riverbed. "Guild authority stops where clan ground starts," he says. His hand sweeps toward the canyon walls, encompassing the narrow throat of stone. "You want to argue law, walk back to Aldgate and file a complaint."
    He snaps his fingers. The guards stride past you, boots crunching on sun-baked earth, making straight for the middle cart. They seize iron pry-bars and wedge them beneath the lid of the conspicuous crate. Wood groans and splits. Wax seals crack and tumble into the dust like broken teeth. The guards heave the lid aside and step back. Inside, stacked in careful rows, sit rough-bound books, their covers stained dark with age and handling.
    The toll-keeper reaches in and lifts one free. He opens it, tilts his head to read, then spits into the dirt at his feet. "You would bring such pollution among our people? Shameful." His voice carries the weight of genuine disgust. He beckons the guards closer, already turning his full attention to the merchant, whose face has gone the color of ash. The toll-keeper glances at your pack, dismisses it with a flick of his eyes, then waves you forward. "Go. You are not my concern today."
    You consider asking what manner of text could provoke such revulsion, but the toll-keeper's hand is already on the merchant's shoulder, fingers digging in. The second merchant has gone very still beside his cart. You walk past the rope barrier, boots finding the narrow track that winds deeper into the canyon, and you do not look back.

choices.optionText: Accuse the merchant = Side with the toll-keeper, these merchants seem suspect
choices.optionPreview: Side with the toll-keeper, these merchants seem suspect

single.text:
The toll-keeper's grin splits his weathered face as you gesture toward the over-sealed crate. The lead merchant goes pale beneath his road dust, his hand dropping from the document case to grip the cart rail. "Those are very delicate instruments," he says, and the words tumble out too quickly. "Please. I can pay a special fee, yes? For an exception." His voice drops to a whisper meant to carry. "For your trouble, and for our friend here in the guild."
  The leather pouch appears in his hand with practiced ease. Gold coins catch the sun as he counts them out, pressing a few into your palm before turning to the toll-keeper with the bulk of his offering. The metal is warm, still holding the heat of the merchant's body. The toll-keeper's thick fingers close around his share with the smooth motion of long habit.
  "No trouble at all," the keeper announces, already turning to wave his guards back. "Carry on. Safe travels." The rope barrier drops with a slap of hemp on stone. The merchant clicks his tongue, and his horses lean into their traces, wheels groaning as the carts lurch forward. He looks at you once as he passes, and the gratitude has curdled into something harder. His eyes promise memory. Then the dust swallows him, and the canyon throat stands empty once more, save for the toll-keeper whistling a tuneless melody while he tests the weight of each coin.

choices.optionText: Submit to a search = Follow the rules and hope for the best
choices.optionPreview: Follow the rules and hope for the best

single.text:
You step forward, ahead of the merchant, and offer yourself for inspection. The nearest guard halts, grunts, and begins pulling through the contents of your pack with thick fingers. His face remains flat, uninterested. After a moment he waves you past the rope barrier with the back of his hand.
  You walk through the stone throat alone. Behind you, the argument swells into shouts. Wood cracks, sharp and splintering. A voice rises in protest, then cuts short. The sound echoes off the canyon walls. You do not turn. Whatever lay sealed beneath those wax stamps belongs to someone else now. The rope barrier recedes behind you, and the passage ahead narrows into shadow.

encounters.title: A Son's Responsibility
encounters.body:
The dike is failing. You see it from the raised path — a seeping dark line where the packed earth has begun to weep, water forcing through in thin streams that catch the afternoon light. Beyond it, the paddy fields stretch in careful geometric rows, rice stalks still green, weeks from harvest. A woman stands knee-deep in the breach, packing mud with her bare hands. Her movements are methodical but losing ground. The water wants through.

She doesn't look up when you approach, but she knows you're there. "My son left this morning," she says, voice flat as the water. "Took the boat. Said he'd be back before the tide pressed in." She shoves another handful of clay into the widening gap. It holds for three heartbeats, then a fresh trickle carves through. "He won't be. This is the third time." 

You watch the woman work, and you think you have the gist of it. Cut reeds, bind them with clay, drive stakes into the ground to hold work. With both you you, it would take an hour, maybe less. But the woman's hands pause and she finally meets your eyes.

"I can't let just let the dike wash away, but he needs to see it fail."

The words carry no heat, only weight. "He needs to come back to ash and mud and understand there are consequences." 

A heron lifts from the far paddies, wingbeats heavy in the thick air.

The dike gives a little more. The first paddy will flood soon.

choices.optionText: Help in silence = Just repair the dike and prevent a flood
choices.optionPreview: Just repair the dike and prevent a flood

single.text:
You step off the path and the water takes you to mid-thigh, warm and thick with silt. The woman watches as you begin to gather materials. Clay from the solid bank, handfuls of reed stems still green enough to bend, the long-bladed sedge that holds knots. You work in silence, weaving fascia between driven stakes, packing the gaps with clay mixed thick with chopped stems. The woman stands aside. She doesn't help. She watches the way someone watches a meal being prepared for a guest they didn't invite.
  The breach holds. You pack the last of the clay smooth, reinforcing the weak points with twisted reed bundles that will swell as they soak. The seeping stops. The paddies remain flat and green, undisturbed. The woman looks at the repair for a long moment, then at the distance where the boat will eventually return. "You've bought him another season of thinking he can leave whenever he wants," she says. There's no gratitude in it. She turns and walks toward the hut, feet sure on the raised path, and doesn't look back. You stand alone by the dike, hands caked with drying mud.

choices.optionText: Offer to help = Try to understand what's going on here
choices.optionPreview: Try to understand what's going on here

branches.text:
You step off the path and the water takes you to mid-thigh, warm and thick with silt. The woman watches as you begin to gather materials. "What's your name?" you ask. "Netta." "And your boy?" She sighs. "Wren." You grab two handfuls of clay from the solid bank. "What's Wren gotten himself into this time?"
    Netta steps back from the breach. Not far—just enough that her hands are no longer sealing it. She watches the water claim its ground, jaw set hard enough to hurt. "He thinks I'm trying to keep him small," she says. "Keep him stuck on this farm." The words come rougher now. "But this is what I know. This is what keeps us fed. If he leaves it, I don't know how to follow."
    Another shudder runs through the dike. Clay sloughs away in a slow collapse, and the first paddy begins to fill in earnest. You plant a stake anyway, driving it down with the flat of your palm. 
    "Flooding this won't bring him back," you say. Netta's eyes flick to the spreading water, to the rice bowing under it. For a long moment she says nothing. Then, almost to herself: "I wanted him to see what it costs." 
    "And what if he's willing to pay that to be free?"
    Netta inhales, sharp and shaky. She steps forward and sinks her hands back into the breach beside yours. "Then I suppose I'd be a fool to flood my own farm."
    The two of you work together, mending the breach. It is filthy, exhausting work, but the dike holds.

fallback.text:
"Your boy will learn nothing from this," you say. "Only that he was smart to leave."
    You meant it as cold assessment, a judgment of the futility in letting the dike collapse. But the words came wrong, edged with something cruel you had not intended. They settle in the humid air between you like stones dropped into still water.
    The woman goes rigid. Her hands stop their work, mud dripping from her fingers. She turns her head, and the look she fixes upon you carries no anger, only a frost so deep it seems to draw warmth from your bones. Then she rises from the breach, water streaming from her legs, and walks away without a word. Her footsteps squelch in the saturated earth. She does not look back.
    The dike gives.
    Water springs through the gap with sudden violence, no longer seeping but burbling forth in a muddy torrent. The breach widens as you watch, clay and packed earth tumbling into the flood. The first paddy field darkens as water spills across its surface, swallowing the neat rows of green rice. Even if you wished to stem it now, the work requires two pairs of hands, stakes driven while another packs the clay, reeds bundled and braced. You cannot hold it alone.
    You turn back to the raised path. Behind you, the water rushes on, claiming what it will.

choices.optionText: Sabotage = Weaken the dike further, ensuring its failure
choices.optionPreview: Weaken the dike further, ensuring its failure

branches.text:
You seize a double handful of the sodden clay and wrench it free. The dike groans, a deep sound felt more than heard, as the gap widens. You hurl the mass into the flooding paddy. It strikes the water with a thick slap. Again you tear at the packed earth, fingers sinking deep into the yielding wall. Another chunk comes loose. You laugh as you cast it aside, and the sound carries across the fields like the cry of some carrion bird. Water surges through in a brown torrent that foams and churns, spreading between the rice stalks in dark fingers.
    The woman makes a small sound, wordless and raw. She staggers back from the failing wall, water sluicing past her knees, and her gaze fixes on the spreading flood. Something breaks in her expression, some final acceptance cracking like old pottery. Her hand drops to the earth and closes around a stone the size of a man's fist. She lifts it, trembling, and lurches toward you with the clumsy desperation of one who has never raised a hand in violence. The stone arcs through the air. You move. Your weapon finds her before she can complete the swing. She falls without ceremony into the muddy water, and the stone tumbles from her fingers.
    The dike continues its collapse behind you, water roaring through the widening breach. The paddy fields drink deep, rice stalks vanishing beneath the flood. Her son will return to find the house beneath dark water, the dike in ruins, and his mother cold among the drowned earth. Perhaps he will understand then what it means to abandon what must be tended. You turn from the wreckage and walk back along the raised path, leaving the water to claim what remains.

fallback.text:
You step down into the water beside her. The woman shifts to give you room, assuming help. You reach for the packed clay at the dike's base, where the structure is oldest, and dig your fingers in. The mud comes away easily once you know where to pry. You work a stone loose, then another, opening a channel beneath her fresh repairs. The water finds it immediately, eager, widening the gap from below.
    She sees what you've done. For a moment she only stares, hands still full of useless mud. Then she drops it and lunges. She's strong from years of this work and her fists find your chest, your jaw, blows without technique but full of weight. You go down into the water and she's on top of you, pressing your face into the silt, and you taste the fen, thick and old and furious. The dike gives with a sound like tearing cloth. The flood hits you both, a wall of brown water that sweeps her off and carries you ten feet before you find bottom.
    When you surface, coughing, she's already wading toward what remains of her home. The paddies are gone, merged into a single sheet of water reflecting white sky. You pull yourself onto the path and lie there, ribs aching, face throbbing, clothes heavy with silt

encounters.title: An Unpaid Debt
encounters.body:
The elder sits beneath the meeting pavilion, reed mat spread before her, contract weighted at the corners with smooth river stones. The ink has run a little in the damp, but the seal is clear enough: the Merchant Guild's device, pressed deep and smug. Around the platform the villagers mutter, not wild with anger but steady with it — the sound of people who know when they've been handled.

The guild merchant stands aloof, dry, immaculate, and composed. He taps the parchment with a gloved finger and explains, patiently, that the exclusivity clause extends to "all navigable channels, known or later discovered," that the yield guarantee binds the village irrespective of seasonal variance, and that the penalty for breach accrues at a rate any child could calculate. 

He signs deeply, adopting a patronizing tone. "You promised fish," he says. "If the western channels failed, you should have found others. The contract does not concern itself with disappointment."

The elder's mouth tightens. The advance coin paid for seed after a blight year. For timber when the flood took three homes. The villagers understood a bad season to be a shared misfortune, not an opportunity for interest to breed like midges. They have no fish in the quantities demanded. They do not have the coin the merchant now claims is owed.

The merchant closes his ledger with a soft, satisfied sound. He will accept payment in fish, in silver, or in pledged labor at guild rates. Failing that, he will mark the village delinquent and let the Guild pursue remedies less conversational. The elder turns to you, eyes sharp and measuring.

choices.optionText: Pay the debt = Cover the coin the village owes from your own resources
choices.optionPreview: Cover the coin the village owes from your own resources

single.text:
You step forward and loosen your purse. The merchant watches, amused, as you count the coin onto the reed mat. His amusement curdles into something harder when the stack rises to match the sum written in his ledger. He blinks, mouth slack, the careful lines of his face collapsing into something unguarded and raw.
  The expression lasts only a moment. It smooths away, replaced by a smile that sits crooked and knowing on his lips. "I was like you once," he says, gathering your coin with gloved fingers. The metal clinks softly as he stacks it into a neat column. "I wanted to be the hero, saving these wretched peasants. A year out here in the borderlands will cure you of that." He regards the pile, then pushes it back across the mat toward you with deliberate care. "Keep your coin, friend. You will need it. Hard times to come."
  He draws a long breath, gaze sliding past you to the villagers beyond. "I will see these folks through, just this once." He pauses, "not a favor to you, but to the man I once was." The contract rustles as he rolls it tight and tucks it into his satchel. He waves a hand, dismissive, the gesture final. "Now get out of here before I make another bad decision."

choices.optionText: Side with your fellow Guild member = Insist that the contract is just and valid
choices.optionLink: Side with your fellow Guild member
choices.optionPreview: Insist that the contract is just and valid

single.text:
You take the parchment from beneath its stones and trace the clauses with a careful eye. The ink has blurred in places, true, but the structure remains sound: three seals of the Merchant Guild pressed into wax, each impression crisp and deliberate; the terms of advance and repayment rendered in the formulaic language of commercial law; the interest schedule ascending in neat columns; the waiver of force majeure signed in the elder's own hand. You read the exclusivity provision twice. It is comprehensive. It is binding.
  You set the contract down and meet the elder's gaze. The silence stretches. Around the pavilion the villagers shift, leather creaking, breath held. You speak plainly: the agreement is sound, the debt is owed, and the Guild's claim is just. That the western channels failed is misfortune, but misfortune does not void obligation. The merchant extended coin in good faith; the village accepted it with open hands. Now the terms must be honored, or the consequences will follow with the same inevitability as spring floods.
  The elder's face hardens, not with surprise but with the confirmation of something already suspected. The merchant permits himself a small, measured nod. He reopens his ledger and begins to record the disposition of the matter, quill scratching soft and methodical against vellum. The villagers do not shout. They turn away, shoulders bent, already calculating what can be sold, what can be pledged, what small and bitter surrenders the season ahead will demand.
  The merchant nods graciously, extending you the customary consulting fee.

choices.optionText: Inspect the contract = Find a way out for the villagers
choices.optionPreview: Find a way out for the villagers

branches.text:
You lift the contract from its bed of river stones. The parchment is stiff beneath your fingers, edges water-stained and curling. The script runs dense and tight, clause nested within clause like fish traps sunk one inside another. Each sentence coils back upon itself, laden with conditions and exceptions that seem to multiply as you read. The merchant's guild employs no fools to draft such instruments.
    You trace the lines again, slower. Your eyes ache from following the serpentine text. The terms shift and qualify, hedging every obligation, foreclosing every exit. You are nearly ready to set the thing down, to admit defeat, when a peculiar phrasing snags your attention. There, in the third subsection of the yield clause: payment calculated as a *residual proportion* of catch taken from designated channels. If the western channels yielded nothing, the residual collapses to near nothing. A handful of coppers, perhaps. Barely sufficient to pay the merchant's passage to this place, let alone the sum he now demands.
    You speak the clause aloud, voice cutting through the pavilion's tense quiet. The merchant's hand darts out. He tears the parchment from your grasp, holds it close to his face. His lips move soundlessly. His brow furrows deep, color rising at his collar. You brace yourself for his fury, for whatever retribution the guild visits upon those who obstruct its commerce. Instead, he exhales slowly. His shoulders settle. He rolls the contract with deliberate care and meets your gaze with something almost like respect. "Well played," he says. "The error is mine. I will face the consequences." He pauses, weighing you with cool appraisal. "You have a sharp eye. You will go far."

fallback.text:
You take up the contract, fingers tracing the cramped columns of script while the merchant observes with folded hands. The parchment is thick, expensive; the sort of document that carries weight beyond its words. You think you have found it in the third clause, the one concerning seasonal variance, but before you can voice the thought the merchant inclines his head and points to the margin notation, explaining in measured tones how the subsidiary provision negates your interpretation. His voice carries the patience of a tutor addressing a slow pupil.
    You try again, seizing upon the language of "navigable channels." Surely the western reaches, choked with silt and weed, cannot qualify. The merchant does not sigh, but something in his stillness suggests he has heard this before. He gestures to an addendum, its seal pressed so deep the wax has split the fiber, and reads aloud the definition inscribed there. Each word lands with the certainty of a hammer stroke. You scan the remaining paragraphs, fingers growing clumsy, seeking some crack in the edifice of language. There must be something. The elder watches you, and you feel the weight of her expectation like a stone upon your back. But the contract yields nothing; every avenue closes, every hope collapses into qualifications and exceptions nested like traps within traps.
    At last you set the parchment down, your hands uncertain where to rest. The merchant permits himself a small, tight smile. "Well," he says, his voice carrying across the pavilion, "if this august merchant can find nothing amiss, surely the contract is ironclad." He spreads his hands, a gesture of patient magnanimity. "If we are done with this diversion, let us return to the matter of payment." The villagers' muttering has ceased. They watch you depart from beneath the pavilion, and you cannot meet the elder's gaze as you go.

encounters.title: The Cartographer's Kit
encounters.body:
The trader squats on the raised path through the reeds, his punt already loaded, his shoulders hunched against the humidity like a man who hasn't been dry in days. He's sorting through a canvas wrap of goods, mostly common stuff, fish hooks and lamp oil. But tucked among them you catch the edge of something different. A leather bag, a Merchant's Guild seal stamped into the leather. A guild cartographer's kit.

He moves to cover it when he sees you looking, but not quickly enough.

He names a price that would empty most purses. Says he's leaving within the hour, heading upriver to drier markets where people pay what things are worth. The kit is in good order, he says, all the pieces intact.

What he doesn't say is how he came by such a treasure. The kit is the mark of a guild cartographer, each custom made for the terrain and conditions of the area they're assigned to. No one would part with such a thing at any price. The leather bag has a history, and you've every reason to imagine it's a dark one.

The trader is already wrapping his goods. The punt rocks gently beneath him. In another moment he'll push off, and the kit goes with him.

choices.optionText: Bargain him down = Argue that the price is madness for a kit he's desperate to sell
choices.optionPreview: Argue that the price is madness for a kit he's desperate to sell

branches.text:
You rest your hand upon the canvas satchel, not grasping, not yet, but with enough weight that the trader's eyes fix upon it. The hand bears your Merchant Guild seal, turned now to catch what light filters through the reed haze.
    "You have come by some guild property, my friend." Your voice carries no heat, only the flat certainty of stone. "You are fortunate to have found me when you did. Had you sold such a thing to another, who can say what the guild would do." You draw a few coins from your purse, copper and silver mixed, their dull chime like a question hanging in the wet air. "Consider this a finder's fee. I will see that the kit is returned to the guild hall in Aldgate."
    The trader's face drains to the color of old tallow. His mouth works soundlessly for a breath, then another. His fingers, roughened from rope and weather, hover above the coins you have laid before him. He snatches them up with the quickness of a man who fears the offer might evaporate, then releases the leather bag as though its touch burns him. The punt rocks beneath his weight as he pushes off, pole biting into the muck, and within moments the reeds have swallowed him. You hear the splash of his passage growing distant. The cartographer's kit rests in your hands now, its leather still warm from where he clutched it.

fallback.text:
He listens to your reasoning with the expression of a man who has heard it all before. When you finish, he wraps the hide back into his bundle with slow, deliberate movements. Says the price stands or he keeps it. Says there are buyers upriver who understand what the thing is worth, who don't waste his time. He could leave right now.
    You try once more, softer, meeting him somewhere closer to his number. He doesn't even respond. Just settles into the punt and lifts his pole, pushing away from the path with a grunt of effort. The current takes him quickly, and he doesn't look back. Within moments he's around the bend, gone into the reed-maze with your last chance at the kit.

choices.optionText: Steal it = Wait until he's distracted, then take the kit and run
choices.optionPreview: Wait until he's distracted, then take the kit and run

branches.text:
You ask about the lamp oil, pointing to a specific flask, making him turn to retrieve it from deeper in the bundle. Your hand moves before thought catches up. The hide is in your grasp and you're already three strides down the raised path before he shouts behind you. The path is narrow but you know how to run it, feet finding the solid center while his voice rises in anger and disbelief.
    You run until you're out of breath, then hide in the reeds. You wait what seems like an eternity, until the only sound left is the incessant croak of the frogs. You emerge from your hiding place, the kit still in your grasp.

fallback.text:
You gesture toward the lamp oil, voice casual, asking after its quality and whether it burns clean in the marsh air. The trader's eyes remain fixed upon you, unmoving, while his hand settles upon the punt pole at his side. His body shifts, weight sinking into his haunches, and you recognize the posture of a man who has spent years watching for thieves along these waterways.
    Your hand drifts toward the bundle. The pole sweeps through the humid air with shocking swiftness, the waterlogged wood striking your shoulder and chest with the weight of a falling timber. The blow hurls you sideways from the raised path. You plunge into the muck below, the brackish water closing over your head, thick with decay and the writhing roots of reeds. You thrash upward, gasping, fingers clawing through the slime until you find purchase on something solid. When you drag yourself back toward the path, water streaming from your garments, the trader has already set his pole against the muddy bottom. The punt glides away through the reeds, smooth and certain. He calls back over his shoulder, voice carrying across the water: "Stay dry, outlander." The words hang in the wet air long after he vanishes beyond the curtain of rushes.

choices.optionText: Let him leave = Step aside and watch him pole away
choices.optionPreview: Step aside and watch him pole away

single.text: You step to the edge of the raised path. He needs no further answer. The punt slides into the channel with barely a sound, and he poles away with the efficient rhythm of someone who knows water like a second language. The kit stays wrapped in his bundle, its secrets folded into oil-treated hide that will survive the damp journey upriver to markets where people pay asking price and don't ask uncomfortable questions.

encounters.title: The Gatekeeper
encounters.body:
The raised path ends at a sluice gate where an old woman sits on a stool, arms crossed over a walking stick planted in the mud. She wears the loose cotton of the fen-folk and the expression of someone who has judged three generations. Behind her, water pools against the closed gate — your route forward lies on the other side, where the path continues toward the village you need to reach before nightfall. She doesn't move. Doesn't speak. Just watches you approach with eyes that have seen every trick.

"Gate's closed," she says finally. "Stays closed until the paddies on the east side finish draining. Two hours, maybe three." A group of younger villagers works behind her, knee-deep in a flooded field, moving with the unhurried certainty of people who know the water answers to no one's schedule. One of them glances your way, then back to the dike they're patching. The old woman taps her stick once. "You can wait. Or swim. Most outsiders choose wrong."

But you've noticed the frogs have gone quiet in a channel to the south — the kind of silence that means a path through shallower water, if you know how to read it. And the workers are watching their elder more than their work, the way people do when authority is performance as much as fact. Someone laid a bundle of cut reeds near the gate's mechanism, still green enough to bend, and the handle itself is older than the gate it operates.

The sun measures the time you don't have. The old woman measures you.

choices.optionText: Wait patiently = Settle in and wait the full time for the gate to open properly
choices.optionPreview: Settle in and wait the full time for the gate to open properly

single.text:
You find a dry spot near the path's edge and lower yourself to the ground. The old woman makes no acknowledgment, but one of the younger workers wades to the edge of the paddy and offers you a gourd of water without comment. It tastes of the clay it was stored in. The sun moves with the slowness of judgment. You watch the workers shore up a section of dike where water seeps through in dark fingers, packing mud with practiced efficiency. They work in silence broken only by occasional instruction, no word wasted.
  When the paddies finally drain to the old woman's satisfaction, she rises with the care of someone whose bones remember every year. She works the gate mechanism herself, the handle groaning through its arc until water begins to flow through the gap. The path beyond glistens with fresh mud but holds firm under your boots. As you pass, she nods once — not approval, but acknowledgment. You took the measure of things and chose time over risk.

choices.optionText: Attempt the southern channel = Follow the silent frogs through the shallow route you've spotted
choices.optionPreview: Follow the silent frogs through the shallow route you've spotted

branches.text:
You step off the path before the old woman can object, moving toward the silent channel with the confidence of someone who has read water before. She makes a sound between a grunt and a laugh. The mud here holds your weight where it looks like it shouldn't, and the water runs shallow over gravel beds that ring slightly under your boots. Reeds close behind you like a door shutting.
    The channel winds south then west, meandering but passable, and you read it by the silence — where frogs fall quiet, the ground rises enough to walk. Twice you pause at junctions, waiting for the sound to tell you which branch goes deep. It takes longer than the direct path would have, but you emerge on the western side of the paddies with only your calves wet, joining the raised path again well before the village. Behind you, the frogs resume their evening sermon.

fallback.text:
You step confidently toward the southern channel and the mud greets you like an old enemy. Your first step sinks past the ankle. Your second plunges you to the knee in cold water that smells of rot and clay. The silence you mistook for shallow ground is simply where the frogs have learned not to nest — the water here is deep and still, thick with silt that sucks at your legs like a living thing.
    Behind you, someone laughs. Not cruel, but not kind either. You haul yourself back toward the path, reeds slapping your face, boots squelching obscenely with each step. The old woman hasn't moved from her stool. When you finally drag yourself back onto solid ground, soaked to the waist and decorated with mud and waterweed, she taps her stick once. "Most outsiders choose wrong," she repeats, as though you've simply confirmed old wisdom. You wait the full time after all, watching the water drain while your clothes refuse to dry in the thick air.

choices.optionText: Challenge her authority = Insist you need passage now and offer coin or pressure
choices.optionPreview: Insist you need passage now and offer coin or pressure

single.text:
The old woman's expression doesn't change when you make your case — coin offered, schedule explained, importance implied. She listens the way stone listens to rain. When you finish, she taps her stick twice. The workers behind her stop moving. One of them, a broad-shouldered man with gray in his beard, wades out of the paddy and stands near his elder, saying nothing but present in the way that changes mathematics.
  "Gate stays closed," she says, each word deliberate as a hammer stroke. "Water doesn't care about your coin. Dike doesn't care about your hurry. East paddies flood if I open now, and that's a season's rice drowned for someone else's schedule." She shifts on her stool, settling in. "You want to swim, swim. Want to wait, wait. Want to try moving me?" She glances at the worker beside her, then back to you. "My grandson here would enjoy the exercise."
  You move to try to traverse the swamp, but recognize the futility. You find a stump and fix the woman in your gaze, making certain she knows your annoyance. A few hours pass and the gate opens, just as promised.

choices.optionText: Offer to help with the work = Join the workers to speed the draining and earn passage
choices.optionLink: Offer to help with the work

single.text:
You wade into the paddy before asking permission, mud sucking at your boots, and take a place beside the workers shoring up the dike. For a moment no one speaks. Then the nearest one, a woman with strong hands and knowing eyes, shows you without words where to pack mud, how to angle it so the water's weight becomes the seal's strength. The work is harder than it looks. Your back complains. The mud is heavy and cold and smells of fish and old roots.
  But you feel the moment they accept you — not as one of them, but as someone willing to stand in their water and do their work without complaint. The old woman doesn't praise you, but when the draining is complete and she works the gate mechanism, she nods toward the path. "Go on, then. You paid your way." One of the younger workers grins, gaps in his teeth, and claps your shoulder with a muddy hand. You reach the village as the lamps are being lit, soaked and tired but arriving with the dignity of someone who earned passage rather than purchased or demanded it. Your clothes will dry. The ache in your back is the cost of traveling honestly through country that doesn't owe you anything.

encounters.title: The Hunted Woman
encounters.body:
You round the bend in the channel and find a woman waist-deep in the water, braced against a stilt-post. Her eyes track something behind you, back the way you came. She's breathing hard, clutching a bundle wrapped in oiled cloth to her chest. When she sees you, her hand moves to a gutting knife at her belt, then stops. The frogs have gone silent. In the distance, a punt pole taps against wood in steady rhythm. Getting closer.

She hisses at you, not words, just sound. A warning or a plea, you can't tell which. The bundle shifts against her chest and you catch a glimpse of carved wood, dark with age, wrapped in red cord. The tapping grows louder. Two figures pole into view behind you, maybe fifty yards back. They move with the efficient rhythm of locals, but they're watching the channels ahead, not the water beneath them. Hunting.

The woman jerks her head toward a narrow side channel choked with reeds. She could slip through there if you give her time. Or you could step aside, let the pursuers see her, let village justice sort itself. The bundle in her arms looks old. The kind of thing that has a place it belongs, and people who remember where that place is. The punt pole taps closer. The woman's knuckles are white around the knife handle.

The pursuers will reach this bend in moments. Whatever she's taken, it matters enough to chase into the fen.

choices.optionText: Distract the pursuers = Call out to the approaching figures, drawing their attention to you while the woman slips away
choices.optionPreview: Call out to the approaching figures, drawing their attention to you while the woman slips away

single.text:
You step into the center of the channel and raise your hand in greeting. Your voice carries across the water, casual, asking about the fishing or the depth ahead or anything that sounds like an outsider's question. The two figures slow their poling. One of them answers, wary but polite, the way locals do when they're deciding whether you're trouble. You keep talking, gesturing back the way you came, describing a bird you saw or a marker you're looking for. Anything to hold their eyes on you.
  The woman is gone. You catch the faintest rustle of reeds closing behind her, then nothing. The pursuers pole closer, their faces clearer now. They're young, maybe brothers, with the hard hands of fish-trap builders. One of them asks if you've seen anyone else in the channels. You tell them no, and the lie sits easy in your mouth because you don't know what she took or why they want it back. They exchange a look, then push past you without another word, poling hard toward the eastern channels where the water opens up. They think she went that way. By the time they realize their mistake, she'll be deep in the reeds where the paths only animals know.
  The frogs start up again, slow at first, then building to their usual roar.

choices.optionText: Let them pass = Allow the pursuers to find what they're hunting
choices.optionPreview: Allow the pursuers to find what they're hunting

single.text:
You pole to the side of the channel, making room. The woman's face hardens into something beyond fear. She presses the bundle tighter to her chest and shifts her weight, ready to run or fight or both. The two figures round the bend and see her immediately. They don't call out, don't threaten. They just spread apart, blocking both ends of the channel with the practiced ease of men who've herded livestock through water.
  One of them speaks her name. Aya. It sounds like a condemnation. She shakes her head, backing against the stilt-post, the gutting knife finally clearing its sheath. But she's waist-deep in water and they're in boats, and the arithmetic of that is written in her expression. The other man reaches into his punt and draws out a weighted net, the kind used for stubborn fish. They're not going to hurt her. They're going to take what she's holding and bring her back, and whatever punishment waits will be a village matter, handled in front of everyone who matters.
  One of the men poles close enough to pry the oiled cloth from her grip. He unwraps it carefully, reverently, and you see what she took: a carved marker post, old wood dark as mud, wrapped in cords that might have been red once. He nods to his companion and they haul her into their punt like a stubborn catch.
  They pole past you without acknowledgment. You wonder if you should have done something, but it's too late now.

choices.optionText: Demand to know what she's taken = Confront the woman and insist on an explanation before you choose
choices.optionLink: Demand to know what she's taken
choices.optionPreview: Confront the woman and insist on an explanation before you choose

single.text:
She stares at you like you've lost your mind. The punt pole taps closer behind you, steady and inevitable. She shakes her head, not in refusal but in disbelief that you'd waste the seconds she has left asking questions. 
  She spits into the water between you and shoves off from the stilt-post, plunging toward the reeds with the bundle clutched to her chest. But she struggles with the weight and the water, and you can see her eyes widen as the pursuers close in. One hurls a weighted net with practiced ease.
  It catches her at the waist. She goes down with a splash and a cry, the bundle flying from her grip to land in the shallows. One of the men vaults from his boat, waist-deep in water, and drags her upright while the other retrieves the wrapped object with reverent care. They're rough with her but not cruel, hauling her into their punt with the efficiency of men who've dealt with this before. As they pole past you, the bundle secure between them, one of them meets your eyes. The look is flat, unreadable, neither grateful nor hostile.
  You take stock of your surroundings, then roll up your pants and fish into the water. You find the woman's knife, wipe the muck off and appraise it. It's a good knife, well made and sharp. You sheath it in your belt and continue on your way.

encounters.title: The Hermit of Sallow Fen
encounters.body:
You smell the smoke before you see the light.

Deep into the fen and your world has narrowed to a catalogue of miseries. Black water sucking at your boots, the ceaseless drone of biting flies, air so thick with rot it coats the back of your throat like oil. The trail, such as it was, vanished yesterday beneath a carpet of duckweed. Since then you have navigated by the moss on the cypress knees and the slow pull of current beneath the water's skin, trusting that the deeper channels lead inland toward high ground and the frontier beyond.

You had not expected to find anyone living here. Nothing lives here that does not bite, sting, or drag itself through the muck on its belly.

Yet there it is: a smudge of smoke above the treeline, yellow-grey against the perpetual overcast, and beneath it, as you round a curtain of hanging moss, a dwelling. The world is generous. It is a shack built on stilts above the waterline, patched with bark and river-reed and what appears to be sailcloth long since gone to grey. Animal bones hang from the eaves on cords of sinew, clicking softly in a breeze you cannot feel. A dugout canoe is tethered to one stilt. On the listing porch, a cookfire burns in a ring of river stones, and over it a blackened pot sends up a steam that cuts through the swamp-stink with something almost pleasant—herbs, root vegetables, something warm and human.

The woman sits beside the fire as though she has been waiting.

She is old, or perhaps merely weathered beyond reckoning; face like cracked leather, hair a white tangle threaded with feathers and what might be small bones. Her clothes are layered and shapeless, stained with mud and tannin. She watches you with eyes that are, against all expectation, perfectly clear. Pale. Amused.

"Sit," she says, as though you are late to supper.

She does not rise. Does not reach for a weapon. She stirs the pot with a wooden spoon and the smell intensifies; rich, savory, undeniably good. Your stomach clenches. It has been too long since you've had a warm meal.

"You'll want to eat before the water rises," she continues, conversational, almost cheerful. "Moon's pulling the fen tonight. The channels you walked this morning will be six feet deep by dark." She taps the spoon against the pot's rim. "If you know the way through, you'll manage fine. If you don't..." She shrugs, a gesture that carries the weight of absolute indifference to your survival.

Her pale eyes drift to your pack, your boots, the shape of what you carry. She smiles. Three teeth are missing. The rest are very white.

"I don't get visitors," she says. "Not ones who last."

Something moves in the shack behind her. A scrape, a settling weight. She does not look back at it.

choices.optionText: Accept her hospitality = Sit, eat, and trade what information you can, trusting that hunger and the rising water leave you little choice but faith.
choices.optionPreview: Sit, eat, and trade what information you can, trusting that hunger and the rising water leave you little choice but faith.

branches.text: You trade tales of the world beyond the fen for bowls of her root-stew, and something in your words—perhaps the honesty of exhaustion, or the shape of distant roads in your voice—softens the pale amusement in her eyes. When you depart at dawn, she presses into your hands a small bundle wrapped in oilcloth: dried fish, hard travelers' bread, something that smells of smoke and keeping. "The fen takes," she says, "but I give what I can spare."

fallback.text: You wake retching in cold water beneath an empty sky, the taste of bitter herbs still coating your tongue and your limbs heavy as waterlogged wood. The clearing is bare. No stilts, no shack, no bones clicking in the wind—only disturbed mud and the half-remembered shape of something vast and wrong that moved through your fever dreams. By the sun's pale climb you have lost the night, and perhaps something more.

choices.optionText: Demand to know what is in the shack = You have not survived in this fen by ignoring what moves in the dark behind a stranger's smile.
choices.optionLink: Demand to know what is in the shack
choices.optionPreview: You have not survived in this fen by ignoring what moves in the dark behind a stranger's smile.

conditional.preamble: The hermit's smile doesn't waver as the thing behind the sailcloth door begins to move, something massive shifting in the darkness with a wet, patient hunger. "My boy gets so few visitors," she says, rising with a mother's gentle pride, and you understand now why the bones hang from the eaves: they are not charms but trophies, markers for those who also trusted their instincts too late.

branches.text:
The sailcloth tears away. Something fills the doorway; too tall, joints wrong. Pale skin stretched tight. Fingers tipped with yellowed bone hooks. A mouth that opens too wide, teeth jagged and uneven. It drops into the shallows. The water barely reaches its knees.
    It lunges. You slip aside. The hooks slice past your throat, close enough that you smell old blood and swamp rot. It is quick but clumsy. You ready your weapon. When it overreaches, you strike. You hit the monster hard with your weapon.
    A thin, whistling scream. It twists, tearing the weapon from your grip. One arm hangs useless; the other sweeps low for your legs. You fall back, snatch a stone from the cookfire ring, and smash it against its temple.
    The crack echoes. It falters. You retrieve your weapon and cut its throat in a single stroke. It collapses into the black water, which closes and stills.
    The hermit is gone. Only the low cookfire and a steaming pot remain. You take what supplies you can and leave the shack behind, bones clicking faintly in the wind as the fen swallows you.

fallback.text:
The sailcloth tears away. A horrid shape fills the door; wrong-jointed, bone-hooked, ghastly mouth splitting wide. It drops into the shallows and lunges.
    You swing your weapon on instinct. The attack skates off its hide. No blood. No pause. A hooked hand snags your shoulder and wrenches you sideways. Another tears through your pack, spilling its contents into the black water.
    You twist free, stumbling into the muck. The things stares blankly at you, twists its head, and begins to lope forward. You flee, thrashing through the waters. By the time you catch your breath, the clearing is gone and so is whatever the swamp claimed from your pack.

choices.optionText: Press on into the swamp = Thank her and refuse, trusting your own sense of direction over the charity of a woman who lives where nothing should.
choices.optionPreview: Thank her and refuse, trusting your own sense of direction over the charity of a woman who lives where nothing should.

single.text: You barely make it a dozen yards before the shack unfolds impossible legs from beneath its stilts and comes crashing after you through the black water, the hermit's laughter echoing across the fen like a crow's cry. You run until your lungs burn and the darkness is complete, finally collapsing in some nameless hollow where the cypress roots offer meager shelter. By the time you manage a fire, you have no idea which way leads forward—only that the smoke behind you has long since vanished, and with it, any sense of where you've been.
